thread.title: Sugar daddy seeking meaningful connection – unless you’re ‘chunky’ | New York Post
thread.title_full: Sugar daddy seeking meaningful connection – unless you’re ‘chunky’ | New York Post

title: Sugar daddy seeking meaningful connection – unless you’re ‘chunky’ | New York Post
text: 3:01 Sugar daddy seeking meaningful connection - unless you're 'chunky' Rob, a 54-year-old commodity broker from Manhattan, meets women on SeekingArrangement, a dating website that pairs young women with men who are willing to pay for a woman's company -- and hopefully more. We followed Rob on one of his dates at American Cut Midtown , a posh steakhouse in New York City to find out what it's like when a sugar daddy wines and dines a potential sugar baby. 3:33 This New Yorker is 82, bisexual and feeling randy An 82-year-old singer-songwriter from New York City is looking for a good time. D'yan Forest says that while many of her friends have given up on sex, she'll never stop craving intimacy. "It ain't over 'til the fat lady's dead," Forest told The Post with a chuckle. The performer, who identifies as bisexual, sings about checking out the boys and girls on Tinder and says her desire to date is greater than ever. Video produced for the NY Post by Elettra Fiumi and Lea Khayata of Granny Cart Productions. 1:38 This video about boobs will also teach you about words Everyone knows what cleavage means, but where did the word originally come from? It actually originates from Hollywood and the severe censorship standards of the 1940s. Video research from "Totally Scripted: Idioms, Words and Quotes from Hollywood to Broadway That Have Changed the English Language" by Josh Chetwynd (Lyons Press). 2:33 A New York gem: This woman is 'mother' to hundreds of pigeons Tina Pińa Trachtenberg is a true character in NYC, where she is known as Mother Pigeon . Aside from just feeding the birds, she creates pigeon sculptures and displays them, in an effort to help spread more positivity about the unpopular bird. 2:41 This Japanese rockstar was on a mission to play himself to death Despite being one of the world's most successful rock stars, drummer and composer Yoshiki almost gave in to thoughts of suicide. After tragedy surrounding his band, X Japan, and his personal life, Yoshiki has used music to heal, recently completing a sold-out two-night stint at Carnegie Hall. 1:28 We were inside the 'Deploraball' and it was actually kind of tame The new republicans think they are "totally punk rock". On the eve of the inauguration, a group of Trump's supporters threw an event called the "Deploraball," based on a comment made by Hillary Clinton and we were one of the few camera crews allowed inside. 2:30 Old ladies' hula-hooping, rollerskating tricks put young pups to shame Three ladies who call themselves “the skating hula hoopers” prove it’s never too late to have fun. Edna Davoll, 79, and her two friends, Joan and Donna, skate all over the city at least three times a week. Davoll was first introduced to rollerskating by her friend at the age of 45. At first, she was skeptical about being an older skater, but later realized she was hooked — and has been rollerskating ever since. 1:34 Superman transforms into homeless Clark Kent after mugging For nearly 25 years, a Los Angeles based Christopher Reeve lookalike turned heads on Hollywood Boulevard as a Superman impersonator. But now Christopher Dennis is feeling a lot more like Clark Kent than Superman. Dennis was robbed and had his suit stolen last August, forcing him to live on the streets. Dennis has since set up two GoFundMe pages to help him raise money to buy a new costume, hoping someone will come to his rescue. 2:35 This woman will use a horse to heal your soul Feeling down? A Los Angeles psychic and her hoofed business partner want you to get back into the saddle. Kate Neligan, who calls horse Lindsey her "spiritual teacher and best friend, "believes horses can teach humans lessons about confidence, teamwork and overcoming fear. 2:23 This amazing kid has turned the subway platform into a therapy office Ciro Ortiz is not your typical middle schooler. At 11 years old, the Brooklyn-raised boy is not only already fending for himself but is giving back. Inspired by a desire to help, Ciro decided he would set up a stand and offer emotional advice to stressed-out New Yorkers off the Williamsburg L train line. He charges $2 a session, but it's clear his advice is worth a lot more.
